dates.description: A pair of a date pattern to match, and a message to show once the current date at runtime matches the date pattern.

message.description: The message to show when the configured date pattern matches.

command.description:
The inputs to pass to the spawned shell. This could either be a simple shell command, or a script that you pass into a shell or interpreter.
The following environment variables are available to you:
  - `DAY_OF_WEEK`: The name of day of the week. (ex. "Tuesday")
  - `DAY_IN_WEEK`: The number of days after the week has started. Week boundary is set in `week_start_day`.
  - `DAY_OF_MONTH`: The day of the month.
  - `WEEK`: The week number in the year.
  - `MONTH`: The month number.
  - `YEAR`: The year in your system's default locale's year format, usually AD.

run.description: The command or script to pass into the shell/interpreter. If `shell_args` is not specified, then an appropriate flag (`-c` or `/C`) is automatically added to tell the shell to run the input.

shell.description: The optional host shell/interpreter. Accepts a path to an executable or just the executable name if it is already in the PATH. Defaults to `sh` on Linux/macOS, and `cmd.exe` on Windows.

shell_args.description: Optional shell arguments as an array to pass to the shell/interpreter. If this is specified, then `occasion` will not add the script flag (`-c` or `/C`) for you. Keep in mind that the command/script in `run` is added last.

time.description: The date pattern to match. Also define `merge_strategy` if you want to change how this property and `condition` are merged togheter.

day_of.description: The day to match. Can be *either* a day of the week *or* a day of the month. Leaving this empty means it will match for every day.

week.description: The day of the week this pattern will match. Accepts either the full day name, like 'Tuesday', or a shortened form, like 'Tue'. Case-insensitive.

month.description: The day of the month this pattern will match. Accepts a number from 1-31.
The month to match. Accepts the full month name, like 'April', or a shortened name, like 'Apr'. Case-insensitive.

year.description: The year (in your system's default locale's year format, usually AD) to match. Accepts a positive number.

condition.description: The custom predicate to match. Also define `merge_strategy` if you want to change how this property and `time` are merged togheter.

shell.description:
The inputs to pass to the spawned shell. This could either be a simple shell command, or a script that you pass into a shell or interpreter. A return code of 0 means `true`, any other value means `false`. Also define `merge_strategy` if you want to change how this property and `predicate` are merged togheter.
The following environment variables are available to you:
  - `DAY_OF_WEEK`: The name of day of the week. (ex. "Tuesday")
  - `DAY_IN_WEEK`: The number of days after the week has started. Week boundary is set in `week_start_day`.
  - `DAY_OF_MONTH`: The day of the month.
  - `WEEK`: The week number in the year.
  - `MONTH`: The month number.
  - `YEAR`: The year in your system's default locale's year format, usually AD.

run.description: The command or script to pass into the shell/interpreter. If `shell_args` is not specified, then an appropriate flag (`-c` or `/C`) is automatically added to tell the shell to run the input.

shell.description: The optional host shell/interpreter. Accepts a path to an executable or just the executable name if it is already in the PATH. Defaults to `sh` on Linux/macOS, and `cmd.exe` on Windows.

shell_args.description: Optional shell arguments as an array to pass to the shell/interpreter. If this is specified, then `occasion` will not add the script flag (`-c` or `/C`) for you. Keep in mind that the command/script in `run` is added last.

predicate.description:
A custom boolean expression to evaluate. Useful if you do not want to evaluate shell args. Also define `merge_strategy` if you want to change how this property and `shell` are merged togheter.
The following environment variables are available to you:
  - `DAY_IN_WEEK`: The number of days after the week has started. Week boundary is set in `week_start_day`.
  - `DAY_OF_MONTH`: The day of the month.
  - `WEEK`: The week number in the year.
  - `MONTH`: The month number.
  - `YEAR`: The year in your system's default locale's year format, usually AD.

merge_strategy.description: If `shell` and `predicate` are both defined, This defines how both results should be combined. Accepts boolean operators `AND (and/both/&)`, `OR (or/any/|)`, `XOR (xor/either/^)`, `NAND (nand)` and `NOR (nor/neither)`.

If `time` and `condition` are both defined, This defines how both results should be combined. Accepts boolean operators `AND (and/both/&)`, `OR (or/any/|)`, `XOR (xor/either/^)`, `NAND (nand)` and `NOR (nor/neither)`.

multiple_behavior.description:
This option describes what `occasion` should do when multiple configured dates match. Possible options are:
  - `first`, which shows only the first (highest) configured message
  - `last`, which shows only the last (lowest) configured message
  - `random`, which shows a random message
 - `all`, which is an object with a key `seperator` which configures the seperator between the messages.

week_start_day.description: The day name in which marks the start of the new week. Accepts either the full day name, like 'Tuesday', or a shortened form, like 'Tue'. Case-insensitive. Defaults to Sunday if not specified.
